hints_html:
Can you see why the sequence {bn} is decreasing? How does that help show that the sequence is convergent?

To show that a decreasing sequence bn converges, you have to show that it is bounded.

Let’s consider a few simpler examples to understand the relation between an and bn better.

E.g. consider the sequence

\[\begin{aligned} a_n = (-1)^n \quad \text{for all } n \geq 1\end{aligned}\]

or the other sequence

\[\begin{aligned} a_n = \sin\left(\frac{n}{10}\right) \quad \text{for all } n \geq 1\end{aligned}\]

Both sequences are bounded and satisfy

\[\begin{aligned} -1 \leq a_n \leq 1 \quad\text{for all } n \geq 1\end{aligned}\]

Now in each case, consider the corresponding sequence bn as describe in the question and observe. Note that those two cases are fairly easy as what will happen to that sequence (which you should be able to show converges).

A more subtle case to consider after these two is the case of the sequence

\[\begin{aligned} a_n = \frac{n+10}{n}\sin\left(\frac{n}{10}\right) \quad \text{for all } n \geq 1\end{aligned}\]

Notice that the first rational term converges to 1, but because of the sine term, that sequence will never converge. What will happen to the corresponding sequence bn in this case? Why does bn converge?

question: 10 (b)
sols_html:
The sequence {an} is bounded, which means that there exists a real number M such that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle | a_n | \leq M \quad \text{for all } n \geq 1\end{aligned}\]

Hence the supremum of all the numbers an is at most M and by definition of the numbers bn we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle |b_n| \leq M \quad \text{for all } n \geq 1\end{aligned}\]

or in other words, the sequence {bn} is bounded as well. That sequence will be converging if it is decreasing, that is if

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle b_{n+1} \leq b_n \quad \text{for all } n \geq 1\end{aligned}\]

Which we can easily show to be true. Indeed, if we denote by

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle B_n = \{ a_m \mid m \in \mathbb{N} \text{ s.t. } m \geq n \} \quad \text{for all } n \geq 1\end{aligned}\]

then

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle b_n = \sup(B_n) \quad \text{for all } n \geq 1\end{aligned}\]

and clearly

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle B_{n+1} \subseteq B_n \quad \text{for all } n \geq 1\end{aligned}\]

and by part (a) we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle b_{n+1} = \sup(B_{n+1}) \leq \sup(B_n) = b_n\end{aligned}\]

This concludes our proof.

Advanced note: We call the limit of this convergent sequence the limit superior of the original sequence {an}.

statement_html:
Let \(\{a_n\}_{n=1}^\infty\) be a bounded sequence of real numbers. For each \(n \in \mathbb N\) define

\[\begin{aligned} b_n = \sup \{ a_m \mid m \in \mathbb{N} \text{ s.t. } m \geq n \} .\end{aligned}\]

Prove that \(\{b_n\}_{n=1}^\infty\) is a convergent sequence. (You may use part (a)).
